title: Homework 2: Programming in R
text: Purpose: This program seeks to complete the exercises listed in Homework 2, for ST558. The exercises primaily consist of vector manipulation, data frame creation, and simple R arithmetic. General markup and explanations will be provided throughout.

title: Homework 2: Programming in R
text:
Task 1:
First define the vectors “pre_treat” and “post_treat” as blood pressure before and after treatment, respectively. The names function allows us to name the respective columns. Then define “change_BP” as the change in blood pressure for each patient.

pre_treat <- c(120, 151, 125, 126, 115, 132, 132, 129, 134, 139, 127, 122, 127, 135, 133, 128, 147, 138, 140, 132)
names(pre_treat) <- paste("Subject", 1:20, sep = "_")

post_treat <- c(127, 145, 135, 122, 115, 122, 123, 126, 126, 129, 132, 146, 120, 114, 121, 120, 128, 120, 133, 115)
names(post_treat) <- paste("Subject", 1:20, sep = "_")

change_BP <- post_treat - pre_treat
print(change_BP)

 Subject_1  Subject_2  Subject_3  Subject_4  Subject_5  Subject_6  Subject_7 
         7         -6         10         -4          0        -10         -9 
 Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 Subject_11 Subject_12 Subject_13 Subject_14 
        -3         -8        -10          5         24         -7        -21 
Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 Subject_20 
       -12         -8        -19        -18         -7        -17 


Calculate the average blood pressure using the mean() function. Then determine which patients experienced a decrease in blood pressure, and subset the vector accordingly. Lastly, find the mean average decrease in blood pressure.

mean(change_BP)

[1] -5.65

which(change_BP <0)

 Subject_2  Subject_4  Subject_6  Subject_7  Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 
         2          4          6          7          8          9         10 
Subject_13 Subject_14 Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 
        13         14         15         16         17         18         19 
Subject_20 
        20 

pos_change_BP <- (change_BP[change_BP < 0])

mean(pos_change_BP)

[1] -10.6

title: Homework 2: Programming in R
text:
Task 2:
Creating a blood pressure data frame using the vectors we created in task 1. Note that the data is subset to only include negative differences (lowered blood pressure), and a 5th column is created to determine if the post blood pressure is below 120. Knitr is used to output a nice clean table.

bp_df <- data.frame(c(1:20), pre_treat, post_treat, change_BP)
names(bp_df) = c("patient", "pre_bp", "post_bp", "diff_bp")
bp_df <- bp_df[bp_df$diff_bp < 0,]
bp_df$post120 <- (bp_df$post_bp < 120)

knitr::kable(bp_df)

title: Homework 2: Programming in R
text:
Task 3
Using the same logic, remake the data frame using the new data.

new_pre_treat <- c(138, 135, 147, 117, 152, 134, 114, 121, 131, 130)
names(new_pre_treat) <- paste("Subject", 1:10, sep = "_")

new_post_treat <- c(105, 136, 123, 130, 134, 143, 135, 139, 120, 124)
names(new_post_treat) <- paste("Subject", 1:10, sep = "_")

new_change_BP <- new_post_treat - new_pre_treat

new_bp_df <- data.frame(c(1:10), new_pre_treat, new_post_treat, new_change_BP)
names(new_bp_df) = c("patient", "pre_bp", "post_bp", "diff_bp")
new_bp_df <- new_bp_df[new_bp_df$diff_bp < 0,]
new_bp_df$post120 <- (new_bp_df$post_bp < 120)

knitr::kable(new_bp_df)

pre_bp
post_bp

Create a list with the only two elements being the blood pressure dataframes, treatment and placebo. Then use 3 different types of syntax to call the first dataframe. Lastly, we can access the pre_bp column using multiple “$”.

list_bp <- list(Treatment = bp_df, Placebo = new_bp_df)

list_bp[1]
